comments.commentBody: We have much worse problems in this country than John Edwards and his foibles, even if Elizabeth Edwards appears to have been treated pretty badly. We also have worse crooks, (if Edwards really is one) - who have caused fairly permanent problems for this country. Alright, Edwards is not quite a saint and made a mistake, but perhaps it was his naivete that made him fall for the irresistible (?) R ? The errors in judgment concerning the money seem a little hard to believe. Whatever the case, he is no longer a presidential candidate or political hopeful. A sad ending to an interesting career, which seems to fascinate many.

I believe that this episode shows that, at least within the narrow range of mainstream American politics, personal character is not a function of ideology. So let's deemphasize the gossip and ad hominem (and ad feminem) attacks and focus on the boring, complicated stuff.

Now the public can vent their judgment on a man who committed a minor financial abuse. And by the time 'justice' has been done we will have forgotten about the robber barons who 'legally' stole billions of dollars from American families, destroyed communities by forcing people out of their homes, and eliminated the life savings of pensioners who worked their whole lives and were depending on that money to live out their retirement years. And while we're at it we can take money from school children, the elderly, and the poor, so that those who already have the money don't have to give it back. Prosecute the man if you will. But don't let the big fish get away in the process.

What a waste of taxpayer money - is society going to be better off after all this? Maybe he used some campaign funds incorrectly - but there are so many more important issues we should be focusing our energy on.  Edwards should provide pro bono legal services to needy clients  - that would be a fair settlement.

Any device that does not incorporate the infra-red sensor (which is practically ALL devices available today, given that Apple has just now filed a patent for it) would ignore such signals and happily record away. Even when the day comes when all Apple mobile devices incorporate this technology, the sufficiently determined "pirate" could still use a non-Apple device to record shows. Effectively, therefore, this patent accomplishes little.

Well...if excluding the Euro qualifiers, I assume you mean Western hemisphere...and the top match in that hemisphere is probably the one taking place down in Estadio Serra Dourada. I'll be in Foxboro but keeping close tabs on that one.

The "fan guide" for the US match notes that the home side will be wearing red and encourages everyone to "Wear Red All Over". Not sure how smart that is considering the opposition is "La Furia Roja". Also of note, the parking is $40/car - guess they need to come up with the bones to pay Spain's appearance fee.
Thank you Andy and the NYT for this fine compendium of all things hawk cam. This has been an amazing (and educational) experience.

Please keep in mind that while we're all enjoying Pip, other baby birds, Canada geese, are being rounded up and killed by the USDA, as requested by Mayor Bloomberg. Please call 311 and ask the mayor to stop killing these lovely animals.

Dat bridge, onna BEE - KEW - EE, allus tied up wit to much traffic:

From the Polish phonetics, it's "Ka - JOOS -ko,"

no way shape or form is it
"KOSS - kee - oss - ko"

I'm jus' sayin'
Great work City Room!  The map is awesome.  I'm taking it with me to visit all of the nests (can you tell I'm addicted?).

All credit to Barca - they are the best in the world now (thank you J. Cruijff for planting the seeds in the 90s). That said, I can't help but have this most recent run be tainted by two victories against 10 man squads - Gooners who had RvP sent off (wrongly) when they were ahead, and Madrid when it was 0-0 and the special one was employing his "negative football" strategy to perfection. These things happen in sports (just ask F. Lampard about goal line technology), but in back to back games at the 1/4 and 1/2 stages of the CL is particularly problematic....

WOW. This worm had it ALL. Then the affair, conning his best friends,
denying his child, etc,etc. I am so glad he was exposed. It would be tragic to have a creep like him running our country. Running anything.
President Obama is doing the best he can, considering what he was left with. Give him some support instead of all the negative yak. I would sure hate his job.
Edwards should be locked up just for the lack of morals in every thing he's done. I liked him before he showed his real self. What a CON WORM.

Just got the news.  From the very start he was nothing but a sleazy malpractice lawyer.  His was a frightening candidacy because in 50 years I've never not voted Democratic in a presidential election.
Note to self: really got to find something to cover over that Kerry-Edwards bumper sticker still on the car...

". . . former vice presidential nominee says, “I never, ever thought I was breaking the law.”"

This reminds me (perhaps you, as well) of another infamous disclaimer by another famous American:
"I'm not a crook!" -- Richard Milhous Nixon
Money and sex really screw up a lot of lives.  Hope it was worth it.

So he had an affair.... What is beyond comprehension is how a man, who found out his wife's cancer had returned and who had a dangerous affair, merrily announced/continued his candidacy for president. We should abandon further federal expense, heavily fine and disbar him, and send him home to contemplate his future. The same arrogance that led to his undoing surfaced even today in court. So no lessons learned. Time to move on.

In response to Comment #110 "People cheat all the time. We're not exactly programmed to be monogamous. Why anyone considers it newsworthy when a man cheats on his wife or vice versa is beyond me. Granted Edwards may have very well been wrong to use campaign money to hide his infidelity. However, I just don't see how one man cheating on his wife has anything to do with his performance as a politician. Unfortunately, America has this puritan, hypocritical stance that makes infidelity a deal breaker for any politician."

Does it ever occur to this person how important the virtues of honesty and integrity are to the general voting public? Sure, infidelity goes on all the time, but just because people of low sensibilites and moral depravity are so rampant doesn't mean that most of us aren't shocked and dismayed by it.

If a man can jauntily risk with impunity the decimation and cohesiveness of his family by the systematic mockery of his wife and their marriage vows, what other transgressions is he capable of? Most of the men I know put a much higher premium on their word and on their souls. John Edwards had no such inhibitions and had no business vying for President of the United States. Puritanical or not, American voters know that character and honesty are virtues upon which strong leadership is built, and are not dull enough to be out there seeking the Don Juan idiots of the world to lead them. On the contrary,…… a man’s word is his bond. Always was and always will be. I want my President to be an honorable man.

I have not even read this article yet, but my first instinct was to read it and once again, perhaps, give John Edwards the benefit of the doubt, perhaps he is innocent.  After all, I believed his talk about poverty, his talk about the strength of his marriage, and his talk when he said he was faithful to his dear wife Elizabeth.  Why shouldn't I believe him again?  Because I have learned he is not to be trusted.
Well Mr. Edwards there isn't two Americas, there is one America that sends criminals rich or poor to jail.  Hope you look good in orange.

If John Edwards ends up in the slammer ; so should Jon Ensign; they'er small potatoes compared to Blankfine Greenspan and the rest of the financial low lifes though- lets see some of them in the big house !

How many female politicians have been marred by sex scandals? I've never heard of any... only male politicians. Similarly, how many nuns have been marred by sex scandals. I've never heard of any nuns... only priests.

We need to stop voting for men, and we need to recognize the violence and craftiness inherent in so many men. After all, who commits the violent crimes, the Wall St. crimes, sexual crimes, etc.?!?!

Aside from that, if a politician (pastor/priest) is going to abuse money CONTRIBUTED BY OTHER PEOPLE (toward a political campaign/church) or their own personal matters (whether or not it is for a sex scandal, a vacation in the caribbean, etc.), that is a serious problem.

John was a very very wealthy man. Why did he use other peoples' money? And then he keeps trying to deceive the public. We're not that stupid. Something is very very wrong with this man.

For #32, who asked for photos of food and not just words:

The "Great Plate" graphic from the University of Michigan (2008) conveys the same advice, but using a photorealistic plate with healthy, delicious-looking example food. It also gives a bit more detail.

I'm printing it out to post on our fridge for my young kids to see every day. They love dessert more than vegetables -- but they love official rules, too.

The "plate" is too vague to be useful.  There is no sense of portion size or of the suggested number of servings per day from each food group.  And how many "plates" per day is one supposed to consume?  And the cup of dairy is redundant -- the plate already contains a serving of protein, and a cup of water would be healthier and eliminate the unnecessary additional calories.

Yes, as some commenters here note, there is a redistribution of wealth occurring now. But the redistribution is not socialist. instead, it's a massive transfer of wealth from the bottom 98% or so to the top 2% or so. The most massive redistribution of wealth in history, and it's making us into a third-world nation of a few super-rich haves ruling the super-poor have-nots-- i.e., what most of us are on our way to becoming.

And the engineers of this massive upward transfer of wealth are getting away with it because enough of us are easily misled, easily distracted, and easily kept docile with the "socialist redistribution class warfare" bogeyman.
